title-group.article-title: Comments on “Integrating machine learning and molecular docking to decipher the molecular network of aflatoxin B1-induced hepatocellular carcinoma”

contrib-group.aff: Longhua Hospital Shanghai University of Traditional Chinese Medicine Shanghai, China

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author. Address: Longhua Hospital Shanghai University of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Wanping South Road 725, 20032 Shanghai, China. Tel.: 13001661366. E-mail: lh2062@shutcm.edu.cn (L. Xing).

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright © 2025 The Author(s). Published by Wolters Kluwer Health, Inc.

license.license-p: This is an open access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 License, which allows others to remix, tweak, and build upon the work non-commercially, as long as the author is credited and the new creations are licensed under the identical terms.

body.p: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the sixth most common malignancy worldwide and a major global health challenge[1]. Epidemiological evidence demonstrates the combined negative effects of HBV infection and aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) exposure on liver homeostasis, further contributing to the risk of HCC[2]. However, the specific mechanisms by which AFB1 contributes to HCC are unknown. Therefore, there is an urgent need to elucidate the pathogenic mechanisms involved in developing therapeutic and preventive strategies. This article is compliant with the TITAN Guidelines 2025[3].

A network toxicology study by Gao et al revealed RND3, PCK1, AURKA, BCAT2, UCK2, and CCNB1 as potential targets of AFB1-induced hepatocarcinogenesis[4]. We are very thankful to the team for expending a great deal of effort on this interesting study. However, a few key factors should be considered.

First, the authors utilized only transcriptome microarray datasets from the NCBI GEO database to identify differentially expressed genes in HCC. The transcriptome data cannot cover all HCC differential genes due to pedigree, geography, and other factors. We suggest further acquisition of HCC differential genes from Genecard, OMIM, and SwissTargetPrediction to obtain more comprehensive HCC differential genes.

Secondly, the authors used “5-fold cross-validation” for high parameter optimization in the step of machine learning-based core gene screening. As a matter of fact, 10-fold cross-validation has now become very popular. A 10-fold cross-validation can be considered to make the model even better.

In addition, molecular docking was used to verify the affinity of AFB1 with the core gene. Molecular docking is only able to present a static binding pattern of AFB1 to the core genes[5]. Whereas molecular dynamics simulations can observe changes in protein conformation over picosecond to microsecond time scales[6]. We suggest that molecular dynamics can be further performed to enhance the strength of evidence.

Finally, validation of in vitro or in vivo experiments targeting the aforementioned core targets is warranted. The evidence from model animals and cells is more convincing. It might even be worth considering using the patient’s tissue samples for verification.

In conclusion, this study provides a comprehensive perspective that greatly deepens our understanding of AFB1 contributing to the pathogenesis of HCC. We are honored to provide our suggestions and look forward to future contributions from Gao et al. and others in the field of HCC research.

fn.p: Sponsorships or competing interests that may be relevant to content are disclosed at the end of this article.
